newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Former British minister Rifkind joins BHP.
newsitem.headline: Former British minister Rifkind joins BHP.

text.p: Giant Australian resources group BHP announced on Tuesday that former British foreign secretary Malcolm Rifkind, defeated in Labour's May election landslide, would join BHP as a part-time director of its oil division.
"Malcolm Rifkind brings to the Company an invaluable understanding of international affairs," Broken Hill Pty Co (BHP) Petroleum chief executive John O'Connor said.

"His wide experience of foreign policy will significantly reinforce BHP Petroleum's drive to develop a portfolio of high value exploration and production activities across the globe and will also enable the Company to better assess and manage political risk," O'Connor said in a statement.
Rifkind would work part-time with BHP Petroleum as director of international strategy, advising on BHP's plans to develop specific oil and gas projects, BHP said.

Rifkind, a Scottish lawyer who was considered before the May 2 election as a candidate to replace John Major as Conservative Party leader, was forced to quit politics after he lost his Edinburgh seat in the rout by Labour.
Rifkind was a cabinet minister for 11 years and had been Britain's foreign minister since July 1995.
